title: 7 Days in the Yucatán Peninsula
subtitle: From Caribbean Beaches to Ancient Pyramids
meta_title: Yucatán Peninsula 7-Day Itinerary - Complete Travel Guide 2025
meta_description: The perfect week in Mexico's Yucatán: Caribbean beaches in Cancún and Tulum, Mayan ruins at Chichén Itzá, cenotes, and colonial Valladolid. Day-by-day guide with hotels and tips.
hero_alt: Tulum ruins overlooking the turquoise Caribbean Sea
introduction: The Yucatán Peninsula offers Mexico's most iconic combination: pristine Caribbean beaches, ancient Mayan pyramids, mysterious cenotes, and colorful colonial towns. This 7-day itinerary takes you from the resort beaches of Cancún through bohemian Tulum, historic Valladolid, and the wonder of Chichén Itzá—hitting every highlight while maintaining a relaxed pace.
best_time: November to April for best weather; avoid Spring Break (March) for fewer crowds
highlights: Explore the cliff-top ruins of Tulum

days.title: Arrive in Cancún
days.description: Arrive at Cancún International Airport (CUN) and transfer to your hotel in the Hotel Zone. Spend the afternoon recovering from travel on Playa Delfines, one of Cancún's most beautiful public beaches with the iconic Cancún sign. Watch the sunset over the lagoon from your hotel.
activities: Sunset dinner at Puerto Madero or Lorenzillo's
tips: Book airport transfer in advance or use ADO bus ($12 USD)
Hotel Zone beaches are all public—bring your own towel
Avoid timeshare sellers at the airport

days.title: Cancún Beaches & Isla Mujeres
days.description: Take the morning ferry to Isla Mujeres (30 minutes from Puerto Juárez). Rent a golf cart to explore this charming island, swim at Playa Norte (consistently rated Mexico's best beach), snorkel at the underwater sculpture museum MUSA, and enjoy fresh ceviche with ocean views.
tips: First ferry at 5:30am catches sunrise
Golf carts rent for $45-60/day
Last ferry back is around 11:30pm

days.title: Transfer to Tulum via Cenotes
days.description: Drive south to Tulum (2 hours), stopping at the Ruta de los Cenotes near Puerto Morelos. Swim in magical underground cenotes like Cenote Azul or Kin Ha. Arrive in Tulum mid-afternoon and explore the beach zone with its famous bohemian beach clubs and jungle boutique hotels.
activities: Drive Ruta de los Cenotes (2-3 cenotes)
tips: Rent a car for flexibility (essential for cenotes)
Bring biodegradable sunscreen only—required for cenotes
Tulum beach hotels have no AC—embrace the jungle vibe

days.title: Tulum Ruins & Beach Day
days.description: Start early at the Tulum Archaeological Site before crowds arrive (opens 8am). The cliff-top ruins with Caribbean views are Mexico's most photographed. Descend to the beach below for a swim, then spend the afternoon at a beach club like Ahau or Papaya Playa. Evening is for the famous Tulum dining scene.
tips: Arrive at ruins by 7:45am to be first in line
Bring water and hat—site is hot with little shade
Book top restaurants weeks in advance

days.title: Gran Cenote & Transfer to Valladolid
days.description: Visit Gran Cenote early morning when light beams stream through the cave ceiling (best 9-10am). After swimming with turtles, drive to the Pueblo Mágico of Valladolid (1.5 hours). Explore the colorful colonial centro, swim at Cenote Zací in the middle of town, and dine on Yucatecan specialties.
activities: Dinner at El Mesón del Marqués
tips: Gran Cenote opens at 8am—arrive 7:45
Valladolid is much cheaper than coastal towns
Try local papadzules and panuchos

days.title: Chichén Itzá & Return to Cancún
days.description: Depart at 6am for Chichén Itzá (45 minutes) to arrive at 8am opening before tour buses. Spend 2-3 hours exploring the pyramid of Kukulcán, the Ball Court, and the Temple of Warriors. Return toward Cancún, stopping at Cenote Ik Kil for a swim. Final evening in Cancún for shopping or nightlife.
tips: 8am arrival is essential—by 11am it's packed with tour buses
Hire a guide at the entrance ($50) for deep history
Cenote Ik Kil is touristy but spectacular

days.title: Departure Day
days.description: Depending on your flight time, enjoy a final morning at the beach, last-minute shopping at La Isla Shopping Village, or brunch at one of Cancún's excellent restaurants. Transfer to Cancún International Airport for your departure.
tips: Allow 2-3 hours before international flights
Hotel Zone to airport is 25-40 minutes depending on traffic
Buy vanilla and chocolate at the airport duty-free

practical_info.getting_there: Fly into Cancún International Airport (CUN), Mexico's busiest. Direct flights from most major US and Canadian cities, plus European connections. Airport is 20 minutes from Hotel Zone.
practical_info.getting_around: Rent a car for maximum flexibility ($30-50/day). ADO buses connect major towns cheaply but slowly. Taxis and private transfers are available but expensive. Colectivos (shared vans) are cheap for coastal routes.
what_to_pack: Light layers for AC and temples

faqs.question: Is 7 days enough for the Yucatán?
faqs.answer: Yes, 7 days is perfect for the main highlights: beaches, Tulum, a colonial town, and Chichén Itzá. For deeper exploration including Mérida, Uxmal, or Holbox, consider 10-14 days.

faqs.question: Should I rent a car?
faqs.answer: Highly recommended. A rental car ($30-50/day) gives you freedom to visit cenotes, leave early for ruins, and explore at your pace. Without a car, you'll rely on expensive tours or slow public buses.

faqs.question: Is the Yucatán safe?
faqs.answer: The Yucatán Peninsula is one of Mexico's safest regions. Tourism is the main industry, and the area is well-policed. Use normal precautions (secure valuables, avoid isolated areas at night).

faqs.question: What's the best time to visit?
faqs.answer: November to April is dry season with warm weather and low humidity. Avoid Spring Break (March) for fewer crowds. Summer is hot and humid with afternoon rain but fewer tourists and lower prices.
